column30:
Whenever we receive new brand_topic records (there will be many for a given brand_topic combination), we need to do a “rollup” to determine the current aggregate values to use for that brand_topic relationship in our application.

The brand_topic data will come from [GROOMING: where] during ingestion, and the records will be inserted into the brand_topic table for further processing, with an is_rollup value of false.

[GROOMING] There is an id on the join table. Do we want to reuse this or modify it to an external_id to store one from databrix, if it’s provided, so that we can identify any records that were previously ingested?

----

Rough algorithm:

# Ingest any new brand_topic records for all brands, and place them in our table with is_rollup=false
## Determine estimated_total_reach for each row [GROOMING: data from databrix, or is this derived from audiences somehow?]
# For each brand (with brand_id B ):
## Query for all records with brand_id=B and is_rollup=false and data_date_range within [GROOMING: what’s the duration for the rollup window?]
## Find the max_num_mentions from all the rows for brand_id=B. For each row, derive normalized_mentions = num_mentions/max_num_mentions
## Find the max_estimated_total_reach from all the rows for brand_id=B. For each row, derive normalized_reach=estimated_total_reach/max_estimated_total_reach
## For each row, determine relevance_score=((brand_proximity * brand_proximity * 0.5) + (normalized_reach * 0.3) + (normalized_mentions * 0.2)
## For each topic (with topic_id T ), using the rows with brand_id=B and topic_id=T:
### Create (or update) a row with:

{noformat}id: UUID
topic_id: T
brand_id: B
brand_proximity: avg(brand_proximity from all rows)
estimated_reach: avg(estimated_reach from all rows) // note -- only save this if we also get it from databrix
data_date_range: date range of rollup window
is_active: true?
is_rollup: true
relevance_score: avg(relevance score from all rows){noformat}

This row should update any previously existing row with is_rollup=true and brand_id=B and topic_id=T. There should only ever be one row with those fields.
column182:
Another relevance score calculation to experiment with, once we have real data:

relevance_score = (brand_proximity * brand_proximity * ((normalized_reach * 0.65) + (normalized_mentions * 0.35))

Adapt Context Area Regex Runs for Reloads
column30: The idea is to identify a way to know when to rerun and wipe out a context area data load with a reload of new data when a regex pattern is updated. When a regex pattern is updated in the ‘regex_pattern’ table by Data Science, a new data load will need to be updated to the context area. The initial thought is to receive a notification from the application with an event ID of some kind. That ID could be captured in the ‘regex_pattern’ table and used as a versioning indicator for the context area process to know when a org/brand has been updated with new regex. The context area pipeline will look for these indicators, possibly a mix of a new event ID related to org_id and brand_id, and run a complete reload of data when detected.

column1: Remove long string columns from the stats that Delta Lake collects
column30:
Delta Lake statistics optimization should be implemented by removing long text fields from the statistics collection. Delta automatically collects statistics on the first N columns (default 32) which enable metadata-only queries and file skipping capabilities, significantly improving query performance. However, timestamp and string types, especially long strings, reduce the effectiveness of these statistics due to precision issues and truncation that prevent exact matches. To optimize performance, the dataSkippingNumIndexedCols or dataSkippingStatsColumns property can be used to focus statistics collection on the most selective columns, excluding the long text fields that provide minimal query optimization benefit.

||Table property||Databricks Runtime supported||Description||
|{{delta.dataSkippingNumIndexedCols}}|All supported Databricks Runtime versions|Increase or decrease the number of columns on which Delta collects statistics. Depends on column order.|
|{{delta.dataSkippingStatsColumns}}|Databricks Runtime 13.3 LTS and above|Specify a list of column names for which Delta Lake collects statistics. Supersedes {{dataSkippingNumIndexedCols}}.|

[Data skipping for Delta Lake | Databricks Documentation|https://docs.databricks.com/aws/en/delta/data-skipping]
column62: We have queries that can be run to implement the skipping (actual queries probably need to be run by an admin).

column1: Business Logic: Explore page section 2: Competitor Audience Insights
column30:
As a product manager, I want to see a description of a  hexbin graph and information on new audience segments based on competitor, so that I can identify new audience groups that specific are targeted by competitors.

*Hexbin Example:* [https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-hexbin|https://observablehq.com/collection/@d3/d3-hexbin|smart-link] 

*Design:* [Figma|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?t=ooVxtBgGMd9UBLn3-0]

*User Story:* As a marketer, I need to understand how my audiences compare to my competitors' audiences, so I can identify opportunities to target underserved segments and optimize my marketing strategies.

*Description:* Implement the Competitor Audience Insights section of the Explore page that provides marketers with a comprehensive, data-driven view of how different audience segments (previously referred to as community groups) engage with their brand compared to competitors. This multi-faceted analysis page will visualize audience engagement metrics, demographic overlap, sentiment distribution, and engagement trends across brands in the competitive landscape.

The section will feature interactive data visualizations that allow marketers to explore audience engagement patterns at multiple levels of granularity. Users can compare audience segment performance across competitors through side-by-side metrics, revealing which audience segments show stronger affinity for their brand versus competitors. The analysis will highlight both opportunities (underserved segments where the brand could increase engagement) and threats (segments where competitors have established stronger connections).

*Technical Notes:*

* Endpoint: {{GET /brand/{brandId}/competitor}} and possibly other specialized endpoints since the API note indicates this may need multiple endpoints for the volume of data
* Response: {{BrandCompetitorDetailsDTO}} (structure TBD in backend implementation)
* Data source tables: Will need to be defined by engineering team. Please reference [Data Sources for MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech] page.
* Component dependencies:
** Audience selector component
** Competitor selector component
** Data visualization components
column62:
# UI must match design for Competitor Audience Insights
# Competitor Audience Insight Header: [Copy TBD]
## “Compare Audience Groups based on your competitors'”
# “Understanding a Hexbin graph” Sub-header
# Understanding a “hexbin graph” definition text [Copy TBD]
## “A hexbin graph is used for comparative analysis. It reveals patterns and distribution based on your competitors' target audience groups and your target audience groups.  Hover over a color to see which audience groups appeal to your competitors or your brand.”
## Helpful hint:  Remember each audience group tells a story of how different people are grouped based on habits, interests, or choices.  This leads to better decision making based on real behavior!

column30:
X has the ability to replay only 5 minutes of data on a reconnect, this is really only enough time for us to cycle the ingestor for maintenance. There is a separate process for backfill which appears to be good for 18 hours (the docs say 5 days but testing showed X won’t accept any starting date > 18 hours in the past). We need a way to :

# Detect that the ingestor is in a state that requires backfill (we’ve missed > 5 minutes of data)
# Initiate the backfill in a timely way since once we’ve missed data, we have only 18 hours to get it.

Rewrite the ingestor to make it less subject to silent failure.

* Any failure to read from the data source causes the ingestor to exit
* Kubernetes or other orchestrator will attempt to restart the ingestor and alert operators if this fails more than 3 times (or configurable number)
* The ingestor should save its position and resume from that position in the stream when it resumes
* The ingestor should be able to handle backfill. If the stream cannot be resumed document how to backfill the stream from history, including the stream retention limit.

column1: Reddit compliance - playback existing compliance events into Databricks
column30:
Related to TEP-1418: Reddit Compliance - implement edit support in Databricks pipeline, we need to backfill events from Reddit into the Databricks data warehouse. I do not want to implement backfill the way we did previously because this disrupts stream state; we will need another service to read data from Reddit’s location and stream it into Databricks, then process it inline using the pathways created by the edit post process.

From Reddit:

You are required to also backfill these {{EDIT}} events in order to keep compliance. This is a larger backfill because, not only {{EDIT}} events are more common, they are also larger, since they contain the full body of the post/comment being edited. Due to file size limitations, we were not able to share these with you via Google Drive, and we're instead providing you with a Google Cloud Bucket, only accessible by your team, where you will find all {{EDIT}} events that took place during the outage.
You can find credentials for the bucket, as well as instructions on how to perform this backfill in the document I shared in our Google Drive folder here:
[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TbjEA9OgyGUktlM8dauyz4is-lhph1mqgE5gY9CXAXs/edit?usp=drive_link|https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TbjEA9OgyGUktlM8dauyz4is-lhph1mqgE5gY9CXAXs/edit?usp=drive_link|smart-link]

column1: Business Logic: Explore page section 2: Competitor Audience Hexbin
column30:
As a marketer, I want to view audience communication density visualizations for my brand and each competitor individually, so I can understand the intensity and distribution of brand-specific conversations.

*Description:* Develop a visual representation of audience communication density using hexbin charts for the user’s brand and its two competitors. Each chart provides insight into how actively and densely each brand is discussed across audience segments, enabling marketing teams to evaluate brand visibility and engagement hotspots.

*Design:* [Figma Design|https://www.figma.com/design/U4eAh5Xm51tYKozGaM3QGC/Explore?node-id=4002-39643&t=bswKrfjUEdwXVMBE-1]

*Data:* [Data Sources For MarTech|https://evolve24.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/bgp/pages/3091890181/Data+Sources+for+MarTech]

*Technical Details:*

* Endpoint: {{GET /brand/{brandId}/competitor}} and possibly other specialized endpoints since the API note indicates this may need multiple endpoints for the volume of data
* Response: {{BrandCompetitorDetailsDTO}} (structure TBD in backend implementation)
* Data source tables: Will need to be defined by engineering team
* Component dependencies:
** Audience card component
** Score visualization component
** Reach indicator component
** Tab navigation component for competitor selection

h3. Data Stores

The dashboard will rely on the following database tables:

# *Core Entity Tables*
#* {{brands}} - Brand information
#* {{commgroups}} - Audience/community group data
#* {{topics}} - Topic information
#* {{emotions}} - Emotion categories
# *Relationship Tables*
#* {{brand_commgroup}} - Relates brands to audience groups
#* {{brand_topic}} - Links brands to relevant topics
#* {{topic_commgroup}} - Relates topics to audience groups
#* {{strategy_emotion}} - Connects strategies with emotions
# *Metrics Tables* (to be created)
#* {{brand_resonance_trends}} - Time series data for resonance scores
#* {{audience_density_maps}} - Embedding data for hexbin visualization
#* {{topic_resonance_scores}} - Topic relevance and engagement metrics
column62:
* Create a tabbed interface with three tabs:
** Competitor A
** Competitor B
** User’s Brand
* For each tab:
** Render an independent hexbin visualization
** Use the same color gradient from purple (low) to yellow (high) to indicate communication volume
** Do *not* vary colors by brand — clarify that color = density
** Provide an independent title (e.g., “Competitor A Volume of Communications”)
** Add supporting text: “The Hexbin graph illustrates ‘density’ of communication about the selected product brand”
* Bottom label: “[Brand] Audiences by Volume of Communications”
Include a legend from 1 to 95 on the side
** Enable hover tooltips showing exact density values and audience label if available (e.g., “Barefoot Runners”)

column30:
*Epic-Level User Stories - Strategy Board Pin Board*

# *As* user, I want to pin my “Strategies” in ranked order, so that I can return to them when I am ready to execute.
# *As* user, I want to pin my “Strategies” in ranked order, so that I can return to them when I am ready to execute.
# *As* a user, I want each strategy pinned to be displayed with the total reach, so at a glance I will know my total reach. 
# *As* a user, I want each strategy pinned to be displayed with the date the strategy was provided, so that I keep track based on date.
# *As* a user, I want each strategy pinned to be displayed with the badge associated to the key features, so at a glance I will know my how I ranked my strategies. 
# *As* a user, I want a hover to tell me all the information about the strategy, so that at a glance I can view more details to refresh my memory.
# *As* a user, I want a hover to look exactly like the strategy when presented on the Strategy Board, so that design is consistent, and I am familiar with the layout. 
# *As* a user, I want a html pdf report of all my strategies, so that I can share and save documentation internally. 



Include high level user journey flow

column30:
Research Pendo Software and send request to Brendon. Research other user guides / help / feedback options for competitors.

*A. Clarify usage for Pendo - what we want to use it for:*

* Help documentation
* Customer engagement metrics tracking (Clicks, funnel analysis, etc.)
* Zack’s desire to have immediate access to a generalized landing page prior to being fully onboarded 

*B. Determine if Pendo is required for P0 release?* 

*Questions:*

* Should guides exist inside or outside the tool? 
** *Initial recommendation:*  Guides/Help is available within the tool = to mitigate the amount of customer support we directly provide 
** Wizard (via Pendo) to help with onboarding new users / “Tour” 
** “i” information icon for roll-over for common definitions / any other place where explanation is needed (Noting that all acronyms are spelled out or have the icon available)
** Help and Contact Us - are these separate pages, same?
*** Separate flow for Report a Bug vs. Provide Suggestion (want diff email subject lines)
* PDF or video format?
** Whichever is scrappiest! 
* Direct them to onboarding materials?
* What if a question can’t be answered — who do we direct users to? 
** Are we planning on hiring ? account reps?
** What is the resource plan / for how we leverage existing resources on the team (e.g., Product Mgrs,  etc.)
* Direct email - should be a shared customer support email so that we don’t have a point of failure

Due date not until end of April. Feel free to drop it directly in this ticket! Ideally we could use it to track clicks, product feedback, reporting bugs, and whatever else you’d think it would be useful for. Thank you!!
column206:
11/Mar/25 10:58 AM;712020:49999752-08bf-4dd4-b4da-04d21681799e;[~accountid:712020:d8a72c37-5cc6-4564-982e-e00c896f1911] [~accountid:712020:ca0648e1-dbfc-44e5-b770-617d19bbeee5] With Pendo, we could quickly implement analytics into the MVP to gather real user data, which helps validate assumptions, identify pain points, and make data-driven decisions about what to build next.

The platform is handy during the MVP stage because it requires minimal technical implementation while providing deep insights about how users interact with the product. This will allow us to iterate faster based on actual usage patterns rather than assumptions.

Pendo offers several valuable capabilities:

# User analytics and behavioral insights without requiring engineering resources to implement tracking
# In-app guidance to communicate with users directly within the product
# Feedback collection to understand what users think about the MVP
# Feature adoption tracking to see which parts of our MVP are being used
# User segmentation to understand different user behaviors and needs.

column30:
An extremely common question when looking at a graph of volume or sentiment over time is “Why is there a spike here?” This is typically answered by reading documents, but with high volume topics or entities, it may be difficult to figure out exactly what has changed. Topic Intrusion is a statistical technique for identifying a change in the overall discussion. Our initial prototypes used a Bayesian model around the overall term vectors. This can be generalized to work on target dataset with the resulting output being a list of articles.

---

- [ ] Data or input used is reviewed and appropriate  
- [ ] Work is version-controlled and reproducible  
- [ ] Output is documented and easy to understand  
- [ ] Peer reviewed or checked by a teammate  
- [ ] Stakeholder has seen or approved the result (if applicable)  
- [ ] Story is updated and moved to Done in Jira
column62: Code which identifies articles which reflect high-volume intrusive items.

column30: For better understanding and continued monitoring, we will want to log all context area job runs. This can include duration, records counts by source, and relevancy counts.

column30: We need a way to streamline and assist users with the regex creation process. We plan to utilize LLM’s to help us identify multiple named entity recognition (NER) variations. This could either be utilized to help the user craft the regex manually, or integrate directly into the UI PoC. This LLM is not meant to create the regex, but rather help identify the NER variations, something similar that was done by Salience in the past.
column62: Identify a potential solution that can aid with regex creation and management.
column182: Create a trial PoC with basic LLM and prompt generation. Craft a structured output that provides 5 - 10 entity variations that can be added to regex. Add this component to the UI in a PoC state.

This could include 3 - 12 month size experimentation tests.
column62: Identify the best compute type for an optimal run that balances latency, cost and performance.

* Unit tests
* Schema checks
* Data Type checks
* Null distributions across daily runs
* Day-over-day regression testing and variance checks
column62: Create a robust testing framework that will instill trust into the pipeline.

column30: Once the PoC notebook and workflows prove successful, the code will need to be modularized and structured in a way that can be deployed properly. We need to assess simplicity, ease of use, interpretability, and other robustness.

column30:
Zack’s original user story: 

* As a customer, as I change views, and as I change community groups, I want the Resonance score to update accordingly, based on my filter preferences
* As a customer, I want to be able to not only -'filter by societal view down to product view-, I want to be able to select a second filter, Community Grp, so that I can understand how each Community group changes the data based on the 4 different levels of views.
(note: strikethrough as we are not delivering all 4 views for MVP)

column30:
Original user stories

#  As a customer, I want to be able to select a date range, and have the results reflective, of the date range I select. Including Resonance changes, and the associated Emotional Drivers/Topics, and their Resonance scores impacted during this selected time range.
## *Filtering options to include predefined date ranges* with a rolling 7-day Resonance score for the trailing 3 months.  Trailing Months, 4 – 9, include a month-by-month range selection option. 
# As a customer, when I compare against my competitors and my competitor's brand to my own, I want to be able to select a date range, the Community Grps (All, or select individuals) and the all the data dynamically updated based on my filtering choices
